data.title: frisk
data.meta_description: FRISK meaning: 1. to use your hands to search someone's body when they are wearing clothes to see if they are…. Learn more.

frisk verb (SEARCH)

SMART Vocabulary: related words and phrases

You can also find related words, phrases, and synonyms in the topics:

frisk verb (MOVE)

[ I ]

to move around in a happy, energetic way:

a postcard with a picture of lambs frisking in the fields

frisk | Intermediate English

frisk

verb

us

Your browser doesn't support HTML5 audio

/frɪsk/

(Definition of frisk from the Cambridge Academic Content Dictionary © Cambridge University Press)

Examples of frisk

frisk

With stop, question, frisk in place, this would not have happened to my son.

They're never going to get respect and it's because of (stop and frisk).

Teenagers stand on street corners in poor neighborhoods, checking who enters and leaves, while other gang members frisk strangers and demand to see identity cards.

However, the majority of the people who are stopped and frisked are innocent.

Now, 86% of the people who will be stopped and frisked will have done nothing wrong.

Since all this nonsense has been going on with stop and frisk my building is slowly reverting to the way it was 10 years ago.

She said people were being frisked and everyone had police escorts.

Roof appears to comply; police place him in handcuffs and frisk him twice before driving off.

This is my office and you're trying to frisk a citizen?

These examples are from corpora and from sources on the web. Any opinions in the examples do not represent the opinion of the Cambridge Dictionary editors or of Cambridge University Press or its licensors.
